newsitem.title: USA: IMF agrees to release $330 million for Russia.
newsitem.headline: IMF agrees to release $330 million for Russia.

text.p: The International Monetary Fund executive board agreed on Wednesday to release $330 million for Russia, saying the country's reform programme was on target and the money would no longer be held up.

The new funding, part of a $10.2 billion, three-year loan approved in February, had been delayed because of problems in the Moscow government's efforts to collect taxes that raised questions about overall economic reform.

"Executive directors were satisfied that the Russian government and central bank met their July targets, and are pursuing policies consistent with the attainment of macro-economic objectives of the program," the IMF said in a statement.

The lending agency has been reviewing the program on a month-by-month basis and dispensing additional funding as long as Russia met the program targets. The IMF said that a further disbursement could become available next month if current talks in Moscow show Russia is sticking to the program.
Russia ran into revenue problems during the presidential election campaign this spring when the government apparently slacked off on tax collection enforcement to win support.
In its statement, the IMF board said it particularly welcomed steps taken to improve revenue collection, which caused the delay in the loan tranche.
